review.title: Reasoning in Infinitely Valued G-IALCQ
review.abstract: Fuzzy Description Logics (FDLs) are logic-based formalisms used to represent and reason with vague or imprecise knowledge. It has been recently shown that reasoning in most FDLs using truth values from the interval [0,1] becomes undecidable in the presence of a negation constructor and general concept inclusion axioms. One exception to this negative result are FDLs whose semantics is based on the infinitely valued G\"odel t-norm (G). In this paper, we extend previous decidability results for G-IALC to deal also with qualified number restrictions. Our novel approach is based on a combination of the known crispification technique for finitely valued FDLs and the automata-based procedure originally developed for reasoning in G-IALC. The proposed approach combines the advantages of these two methods, while removing their respective drawbacks.
histories: Workshop on Weighted Logics for Artificial Intelligence, 2015
review.COMMENTS: Workshop on Weighted Logics for Artificial Intelligence, 2015

sections.heading: 3 Deciding Local Consistency
sections.text: Let's be O = (A, T) a G-IALCQ ontology in which A = > β-Q describes a local order that uses only the individual name a. & ¬ The main ideas behind the reduction to classical ALCQ are that it is sufficient to consider tree-like interpretations in which each domain element has a unique role, and that we only need to look at the order between the values of concepts and their exact values. This realization allows us to consider only an endless number of different cases [Borgwardt et al., 2014]. To compare the values of the elements of sub (O) at different domain elements, we use the order of sub (O).

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: Using a combination of techniques developed for infinitely estimated Gödel extensions of ALC [Borgwardt et al., 2014] and for finely estimated Gödel extensions of SROIQ [Bobillo et al., 2009; Bobillo et al., 2012], we have shown that the local consistency in infinitely estimated G-IALCQ EXPTIME is complete. Our reduction is more practical than the automated approach developed by Borgwardt et al. [2014] and does not show the exponential expansion of the reductions developed by Bobillo et al. [2009; 2012] Beyond the complexity results, an important advantage of our approach is that it does not require the development of a specialized fuzzy DL rationer, but any state-of-the-art reduction of the reduction developed by Bobillo et al.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was partly supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG, German Research Foundation) as part of the BA 1122 / 17-1 funding programme (FuzzyDL) and within the Excellence Cluster "cfAED." Most of this work was developed under R. Peñaloza at the TU Dresden and the Center for Advanced Electronics Dresden.

metadata.abstractText: Fuzzy Description Logics (FDLs) are logic-based formalisms used to represent and reason with vague or imprecise knowledge. It has been recently shown that reasoning in most FDLs using truth values from the interval [0, 1] becomes undecidable in the presence of a negation constructor and general concept inclusion axioms. One exception to this negative result are FDLs whose semantics is based on the infinitely valued Gödel t-norm (G). In this paper, we extend previous decidability results for G-IALC to deal also with qualified number restrictions. Our novel approach is based on a combination of the known crispification technique for finitely valued FDLs and the automatabased procedure originally developed for reasoning in G-IALC . The proposed approach combines the advantages of these two methods, while removing their respective drawbacks.
